author: shifu.brian666
title: Focus on MiCA regulation in the EU
description: Getting favorable legislation while there is no clear Cardano vision on what legislation it wants in EU.

f6_assessments.q0: Yes, this proposal effectively addresses the challenge. A quick examination of international sources shows that legislators and policy makers do not fully understand the opportunity presented by the crypto space, so I commend the proposer on the idea to develop a framework within the EU to help address this gap. The development of such a framework in this context could have a significant impact depending on how comprehensive it is and through which avenues it reaches the legislative table. I appreciate that the proposer has identified a specific geographical location to ground the proposal and resulting legal framework. Doing so in this way helps voters better understand the expectations and also the limitations of the proposal. The identification of specific pieces of legislation (MiCA and DORA) which will be compared vis-à-vis the framework also helps focus attention rather than being too broad and overshooting. If the proposal is successful, and the proposer is able to get it to the proper tables and representatives, this project will likely have a significant impact.
f6_assessments.q1: Given the experience and plan presented it is not clear if the proposal will be implemented successfully. While I credit the proposer for a well laid out plan, the feasibility of achieving the plan is not easily identifiable. Component A (drafting) seems straightforward enough and given the experience listed, likely feasible. Component B (get policymaker and legislative support) however is a significant step yet there are little to no details on how these individuals would be engaged, at what intervals, at what level, and for how long. Governments are often monolithic entities that are opaque and slow to change, therefore to assess feasibility, identifying key players within these institutions at the outset would give voters more confidence that it is in fact feasible. This is even more important as not all government representatives are in positions to move such a project forward even though they are within the government. Moreover, under component B, the proposer notes that constant iteration will be necessary but there is no indication of how this will be sustained, by whom, and for how long. I would have liked the proposer to also provide more information on their background, including links to their credentials; as it stands, we are left to "trust" the word of the proposer but this will likely deter many voters. The budget also leaves something to be desired and makes it hard for voters to understand how the proposer reached the specific amount. For these reasons, I neither agree nor disagree that this proposal is feasible, but if unsuccessful, addressing these issues in a future funding round would certainly increase the score.
f6_assessments.q2: Unfortunately, I do not believe that the information is sufficient to audit the progress and success of the proposal. It is unclear how the community would be able to audit the success of the proposal to determine whether it was worth the investment. There are no real KPIs, timeline, or roadmap for how the proposal would be implemented. Given the very murky environment of regulation and legislation writing, it is unclear how the success of the project could in fact be measured. If the document is written and provided to legislators/policy makers, is that success? What if it is accepted but not used? How would the community follow up to find out what impact it had on whatever legislation results? Also, there is no timeline provided leaving voters to wonder how long such a project would take. As a policy advisor myself, I know that these timelines often span years and include many iterations beyond the public eye, however, this is not addressed herein. It leaves me wondering whether the proposer, or the community, could even participate in the way explained throughout. Finally, a significant amount of the money is to complete the work but there is no breakdown for the activities within each component, leaving voters to essentially write a blank check but without a way to track it. While I really support the idea behind the proposal there is not enough information to have the confidence that the community could adequately audit the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: Documenting the Cardano vision in terms of legislation would provide the ecosystem with a common goal to work towards and guidance for lobbyists deployed at governments. It will also create a legal basis to research and refine so potential options and paths will become clear. You could look at it like a form of legal planning. This is of great importance because if there is no legal framework to operate in, there cannot be large scale adoption. This proposal could be extended in the future to other economic powerhouses in the world and create a global legal framework with subsections for each powerhouse.
f6_assessments.q1: Given that a legal framework has been brought up a couple times in the recent past and has created  doubt for certain project's abilities to be executed, there is a need for this as soon as possible. The relevant experience of the proposer is excluding the legal support that is needed, but the proposer intends to assemble a team of experts which is bound to gain some traction. Collaborating with other proposing groups in this challenge could improve chances of getting this done.
f6_assessments.q2: The main plan is explained in the proposal and the author has defined the goal of this proposal, but it does not have a clear plan of action (roadmap) in place for the community to be able to check the progress in case of funding. Nor does it specify when the documents would be ready for use, although I am convinced that as legislations change all the time, there will be a need for constant updates.

f6_assessments.q0: It is logically consistent that to lobby for favorable legislation, it is necessary to understand strategic goals and direction.
f6_assessments.q1: Will the outcome of Goal A be the creation of a Global Cardano regulatory vision document, with EU-specific components? If so, the proposal does not lay out a progressive detailed plan to achieve this document, therefore confidence in achieving Goal A and B are lower than highly likely.
f6_assessments.q2: Operating from the perspective that this proposal exists to deliver Goal A and Goal A is achieved by the delivery of a Cardano regulatory vision document, the specific, measurable, time-fenced, auditable plan is not in this proposal and therefore cannot be audited by the community in order to determine progress or likely success.

f6_assessments.q0: Great idea. I buy into the vision of global Cardano vision on regulation. I share in the principle of making clear what regulation on regulation we want for the Cardano ecosystem rather than waiting on politicians to impose one on us. This is brilliant and it is very focused and gives confidence at the lobbying table since it proposal clear what we want. Also, try building cooperation with Crypto 4 EU since both are aiming to work in the same region. I would like to see this proposal get support it needs.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team has great lobbying experience. Having skin on the table is great to have a starting point in the regulatory space and demonstrate commitment to compliance. 

I think the plan is achievable with clear and practical outcomes.
f6_assessments.q2: Gaol and A and B are focused and transparent which would be easy to track and audit. The activity is precise and clear. I think the proposal should be given the support it needs.

solution: Document first a clear global Cardano vision on regulation and 2nd a EU regulatory vision, taking into account MICA, DORA and other
experience: I have been 15 years in Risk & Compliance for financial institutions including many years as a Risk & Compliance lead for Fintechs
